docs.lead_paragraph: Clutching a tiny Bible, Gilda Velasquez leans over her son as he falls asleep with the help of a powerful sedative and a catchy cartoon jingle playing on a hand-held TV.

docs.lead_paragraph: The backers of former Gov. Rick Perry say his policies spurred jobs, but many economists contend that differences in state policies play a limited role in fueling growth.

headline.main: Rick Perry Hones His Image as ‘Texas Miracle’ Fades
headline.print_headline: As Texas’ ‘Miracle’ Fades, a Closer Look at Policy

docs.abstract: Unemployment rate in Texas is well below national average of 5.4 percent, but oil industry is losing jobs as falling oil prices cause shut downs in drilling and production; supporters of former Gov Rick Perry say policies during his tenure were vital to job growth, but many economists say differences in state policies have only limited role in encouraging economic prosperity.
docs.snippet: The backers of former Gov. Rick Perry say his policies spurred jobs, but many economists contend that differences in state policies play a limited role in fueling growth.

byline.contributor: Clifford Krauss reported from Houston, and Nelson D. Schwartz from New York.
byline.original: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS and NELSON D. SCHWARTZ

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court could wipe away health insurance for millions of Americans when it resolves the latest legal fight over President Barack Obama's health overhaul. But would the court take away a benefit from so many people? Should the justices even consider such consequences?

headline.main: How Do Justices Weigh Loss of Health Insurance for Millions?
headline.print_headline: How Do Justices Weigh Loss of Health Insurance for Millions?

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal plans to make an announcement in New Orleans this month on whether to join the crowded field of candidates seeking his party's 2016 presidential nomination.

headline.main: Republican Jindal to Announce 2016 White House Plans This Month
headline.print_headline: Republican Jindal to Announce 2016 White House Plans This Month

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate approved legislation that would make California the first state to extend health coverage to children who are in the country illegally and seek federal authorization to sell private insurance to immigrants without documentation.

headline.main: California: Bill Would Extend Insurance to Young Immigrants
headline.print_headline: California: Bill Would Extend Insurance to Young Immigrants

docs.abstract: California Senate approves bill to allow those under 19 years of age from low-income families to qualify for state-funded Medi-Cal, regardless of whether they are in country legally; bill would also ask for federal waiver to sell private insurance to undocumented immigrants; measure must pass Assembly and Gov Jerry Brown has not indicated whether he will sign it.
docs.snippet: The Senate approved legislation that would make California the first state to extend health coverage to children who are in the country illegally and seek federal authorization to sell private insurance to immigrants without documentation.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration says that many people had failed to pay their share of premiums, leaving enrollment at 10.2 million people.

headline.main: 13% Left Health Care Rolls, U.S. Finds
headline.print_headline: 13% Left Health Care Rolls, U.S. Finds

docs.abstract: Obama administration reveals that around 13 percent of people who signed up for health insurance coverage under Affordable Care Act in 2015 have fallen off rolls, primarily because they failed to pay their premiums.
docs.snippet: The Obama administration says that many people had failed to pay their share of premiums, leaving enrollment at 10.2 million people.
